Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: GOALI: Graphene THz/IR Optics: Fundamentals and Emerging Photonics Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Description: Graphene is an ultrathin material made of pure carbon atoms arranged in a honeycomb structure of single atom thickness. It has unusually high electrical conductivity and has been investigated as the basis of new electronic devices. The high speed and fast response of the electrons in graphene also render this material an attractive candidate for controlling electromagnetic radiation in the terahertz and infrared, for which the electric field oscillates on a time scale shorter than a millionth of a millionth of a second. In this project, researchers at two academic institutions and the IBM Research Division aim to gain fundamental understanding into how electrons in graphene respond to electric fields on a very short time scale and to apply this understanding to develop new devices for controlling electromagnetic radiation in the terahertz and infrared. This spectral region, while very useful for purposes such as environmental monitoring, does not currently benefit from technologies comparable to those available for electromagnetic radiation at either higher or lower frequency. The project provides graduate and undergraduate students with training in an integrated academic-industrial research setting, allowing the students to benefit from the special expertise available in both types of institution.

Technical Description: This GOALI project investigates light-matter interactions of graphene and nanostructured graphene in the terahertz and infrared region of the electromagnetic spectrum. The goal of this research is to obtain a thorough understanding of the electronic response of graphene in the region of strong free-carrier processes and Pauli blocking of the interband transitions. These investigations on the fundamentals of the graphene electromagnetic response are complemented by studies of the use of graphene for basic building blocks of different photonic devices, including light modulators. The approaches include advanced spectroscopy techniques for characterization of both the static and dynamic response of graphene in the terahertz-infrared spectral region and the development of high-quality gated graphene samples and structures. In this integrated academic-industrial team, Professor Heinz leads the Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy measurements of graphene materials and structures and also has responsibility for studies of photonics applications; Professor Shan leads the terahertz time-domain spectroscopy measurements and has responsibility for studies of the fundamental optical response of graphene; the industrial participants at IBM Research provide materials and fabrication capabilities and expertise.

Project Outcomes Report

Award Title: Collaborative Research: GOALI: Graphene THz/IR Optics: Fundamentals and Emerging Photonics Applications

Federal Award ID: 1411107

Graphene, a single sheet of carbon atoms, belongs to a new class of materials called two-dimensional (2D) materials. These materials are one- to few atoms in thickness, can be easily integrated into heterostructures and other existing device architectures, and possess remarkable physical properties absent in bulk crystals. 2D materials open up exciting opportunities for fundamental materials research and technological applications. 

In this project, a team of university (Columbia University and The Pennsylvania State University) and industrial (IBM Research Division, Yorktown Heights, NY) researchers investigated graphene, other 2D materials, and their heterostructures for new electronic and photonic functionalities. We explored different optical techniques to characterize these new materials. We investigated how charges transport in graphene under the influence of a DC or an AC electric field and how electrical charges move across  the interface between graphene and other materials. We also studied new device concepts involving graphene and other 2D materials as building blocks for control and manipulation of the electronic and photonic properties of the structures.

We developed a suite of optical characterization techniques for 2D materials. These include sensitive methods to determine the sample layer thickness by measuring the interlayer shear mode vibrations, polarization sensitive imaging modalities to measure the magnetic properties, and a near-field optical probe to examine the grain boundaries and defects on the nanometer scale in a non-invasive fashion.  We also developed comprehensive understanding of the charge transport process in graphene and the ground-state and excited-state charge transfer processes at a model interface between graphene/buckyballs. Our studies demonstrated that 2D material heterostructures are a promising materials platform for new electronic and photonic devices. Graphene and few-layer graphene are excellent electrical contacts and transparent electrodes for other 2D materials with diverse properties. In this context, we showed the possibility of magnetic switching by a gate voltage without an electrical current in a graphene/2D magnetic semiconductor/graphene heterostructure. We also demonstrated a wide-range tuning of the optical properties of graphene/2D semiconductor/graphene heterostructures. These device concepts may find applications in memory technology, photonics, and sensing applications.  

The close industry-academia collaboration provided exceptional opportunities for student training. During the project, five graduate students, two undergraduate students and six postdoctoral researchers (across the combined team) received broad interdisciplinary training and experience in collaborative research through this program.  Within this group of these junior research participants, about 40% were female. These research participants developed expertise in state-of-the-art nanoscale technology, electrical, and optical measurements, 2D material preparation, and device fabrication, as well as in the preparation of scientific results for publication and presentation at professional meetings
